details.description: Rights for interns and students in the workplace
details.body:
An internâ€™s rights depends on their employment status.

The term ‘intern’ has no legal status, but an intern may have rights depending on their employment status and whether they’re classed as:

  • a worker
  • a volunteer
  • an employee

If an intern does regular paid work for an employer, they may qualify as an employee and be eligible for employment rights.

Student internships

Students required to do an internship for less than 1 year as part of their studies aren’t entitled to the National Minimum Wage.

If an internship only involves shadowing an employee, ie no work is carried out by the intern, the employer doesn’t have to pay the minimum wage.

Voluntary workers

You’re not entitled to the minimum wage if both the following apply:

  • you’re working for a charity, voluntary organisation, associated fund raising body or a statutory body
  • you don’t get paid, except for limited benefits (eg reasonable travel or lunch expenses)

Work experience placements

Work experience students of compulsory school age, ie under 16, aren’t entitled to the minimum wage.

Make a complaint

To make a complaint or for further advice, contact the Pay and Work Rights helpline.

Pay and Work Rights helpline

0800 917 2368
